plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A popular ornamental tree known for its large, fragrant, and tulip-shaped flowers that appear early in the spring before the leaves. It is often cultivated in temperate regions worldwide.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer magnolia flowers are some of the first to bloom in spring, often emerging before the leaves, making their blossoms especially striking.

plants.name: Azalea (Rhododendron spp.)
plants.description: Azaleas are flowering shrubs prized for their profuse, bright blooms in the spring. They thrive in acidic soils and are commonly found in gardens and woodland areas.
plants.location: Asia, North America, and garden cultivations worldwide
plants.funFact: Azaleas have been cultivated for centuries and often signify abundance and beauty in traditional Asian cultures.

plants.name: Ocimum basilicum
plants.description: An aromatic herb widely cultivated for culinary use. In warm climates, basil produces small white or purple flowers typically in late spring to summer.
plants.funFact: Sweet basil flowers are edible and sometimes used to make herbal teas, though flowering signals the plant may be less flavorful.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A tree native to eastern Australia characterized by cylindrical flower spikes composed of hundreds of tiny flowers, which bloom mainly in autumn but can extend into spring in some areas.
plants.bloomingSeason: March to May (with some regional variation)
plants.funFact: Banksia flowers are rich in nectar, attracting birds and insects, and indigenous Australians traditionally used the nectar as a sweet treat.
